description.narrative: This project will work to improve health for disadvantaged people who have limited/no access to quality surgical healthcare in Senegal. This will be achieved through undertaking surgeries (including maxillofacial, reconstructive, ophthalmic, general surgery) and dental procedures to improve immediate health outcomes for patients that are unable to access healthcare services (output 1). Health outcomes in Senegal will also be improved by building the capacity of physicians and nurses through medical capacity building training. Various training will be offered according to the specialism, ranging from essential surgical skills, ultrasound, neonatal resuscitation, biomedical technician training, and full hospital surgical teams; as well as a mentoring scheme (output 2). Finally, the development of learning materials will make recommendations to the Senegalese MoHSA for future investment in healthcare provision (output 3).

participating-org.narrative: UK - Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office

mailing-address.narrative: 12 Meadway Court, Stevenage, SG1 2EF, United Kingdom

recipient-country.narrative: The 'Africa Mercy' is a hospital ship, and for this project is docked in the port of Dakar, Senegal. Referrals and screening of patients in need of surgical procedures are accepted from all over Senegal, including both rural and urban areas.

sector.narrative: Output 1 focuses on providing direct surgical interventions for Senegalese patients in need of surgery or dental procedures. The DFID-funded element of the wider Senegalese programme will provide 34 Maxillofacial surgeries; 14 reconstructive surgeries; 117 Ophthalmic surgeries; 56 General surgeries; and 3,243 dental procedures to those that do not otherwise have the means or the access to quality surgical healthcare. Surgery and recovery are provided to patients free of charge.

Output 2 focuses on developing the capacities of Senegalese medical professionals, in the form of short courses (essential surgical skills, neonatal resuscitation, ultrasound, and biomedical training), and mentoring. The aim is to equip medical professionals with the skills and knowledge to share with their peers, for strengthened healthcare provision after the Africa Mercy ship departs Senegal. The DFID-funded element of the wider Senegalese programme will provide training and mentoring for 214 medical professionals.

Output 3 focuses on developing an assessment framework to determine the barriers to surgery in Senegal, and create an assessment framework to identify areas for healthcare systems strengthening and provide recommendations to improve access to surgical healthcare as per the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 4AQ model (Availability, Accessibility, Affordability, Awareness, and Quality).

policy-marker.narrative: Disability reduction through improving access to and quality of surgery.
